This work aims to improve the prediction of Atlantic Multidecadal Variability (AMV) from maps of sea surface temperature, salinity, and sea level pressure in the North Atlantic region using machine learning models. We utilize data from the Community Earth System Model 1 Large Ensemble Project, a state-of-the-art climate model with 3,440 years of data. Our results demonstrate that all the models used outperform the traditional persistence forecast baseline. Predicting AMV is crucial for identifying future extreme temperatures and precipitation, as well as hurricane activity, in Europe and North America up to 25 years in advance.

The Atlantic Multidecadal Variability (AMV) is a basin-wide fluctuation of sea-surface temperatures in the North Atlantic with a periodicity of approximately 60 to 70 years. AMV has significant societal impacts, including anomalously warm summers in northern Europe and hot, dry summers in southern Europe, as well as increased hurricane activity. The state of AMV is measured by the AMV Index, calculated by averaging sea-surface temperature anomalies over the entire North Atlantic basin.

The spatial pattern of sea-surface temperature associated with a positive AMV phase is characterized by maximum warming in the subpolar North Atlantic and a secondary maximum in the tropical Atlantic, with minimum warming (or slight cooling) in between. Despite the importance of predicting AMV, progress in predicting AMV at decadal and longer time scales has been limited. Previous efforts have used computationally expensive numerical climate models to perform seasonal to multi-year predictions with lead times of up to 10 years.

The subpolar region in the North Atlantic has been shown to be one of the most predictable regions over the globe, and associated with the predictability of weather and climate in Europe and North America up to 10 years. An outstanding question is whether such predictability can be extended to prediction lead times longer than 10 years, particularly in a changing climate. Our objective is to predict extreme states of the AMV using various oceanic and atmospheric fields as predictors, formulated as a classification problem.

We use multiple machine learning models to explore the predictability of AMV up to 25 years in advance. The input predictors include sea surface temperature, sea surface salinity, and sea level pressure. The prediction objectives are strong positive (red) and negative (blue) AMV states outside one standard deviation of the AMV Index.

Related work has successfully applied machine learning techniques to predict climate variability, particularly the El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO). ENSO is an interannual mode of variability in the tropical Pacific Ocean, with a cycle of approximately 3-7 years. Several studies have used convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to predict ENSO 12 to 16 months ahead using various features, outperforming the typical 10-month lead time ENSO forecast with state-of-the-art, fully-coupled dynamical models.

However, little work has been done to predict decadal and longer modes of variability such as the AMV using machine learning. The biggest challenge is the lack of data, with widespread observational records for many variables only available after the 1980s, limiting both the temporal extent and pool of predictors that may be used for training. To remedy this, we used the Community Earth System Model version 1.1 Large Ensemble Simulations, a fully-coupled global climate model that includes the best of current knowledge of physics and has shown good performance in simulating the periodicity and large-scale patterns of AMV comparable with observations. There are a total of 40 ensemble runs, each between 1920 and 2005, with individual runs slightly perturbed in their initial conditions and treated as 40 parallel worlds.
